name: places/ChIJN-r9CpRZwokROi4BUGFj5fI

displayName.text: Koster and Bial's Music Hall Plaque

formattedAddress: 151 W 34th St., New York, NY 10001, USA
adrFormatAddress: 151 W 34th St., New York, NY 10001, USA

originalText.text:
A notable bronzed slice of Americana on the façade of Macy's flagship store in New York City declaring, "Here the motion picture began."

Though impressive on first glance, there is more to the story.

One is led to believe Thomas Edison was responsible for the birth of the motion picture industry right here at this former Vaudeville theatre in 1896.

Apparently, this is only relatively true.

It is in fact, the first place Thomas Edison, per se, strung three of his peephole moving pictures together, then projected the result through Charles Francis Jenkins and Thomas Armat's "vitascope" to a paying audience.

However, the first commercial "film" screening was likely projected the prior year in 1895 at the Grand Cafe in Paris.

The United States film industry subsequently blossomed in Hollywood, California, ironically because of Edison's greed for profit.
